Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: The child has been promised a Nintendo, and the mother should purchase it
Expectation2: Fix bugs and troubleshoot issues reported by users or QA
Situation2: A production outage traces back to a defect in their code and customers cannot access the service
Story: I stare at my phone, the screen filled with urgent Slack messages from the ops team: “Production is down. Users can’t log in. Can you look now?” My heart pounds. I know the outage is traced back to a bug in my code, and the pressure to fix it is crushing. At the same time, my son tugs at my sleeve, his eyes wide with hope. “Mom, are we going to the store? You promised we’d get the Nintendo today.” I remember the promise, the excitement in his voice all week, and the importance of keeping my word. But the outage means customers are locked out, and my team is counting on me to restore the service. I feel the weight of both worlds pressing in—my son’s trust and happiness, and my responsibility to my job and our financial stability. My mind races, torn between the urgent demands of my work and the promise I made to my child. I can’t let either down, but right now, I don’t know how to choose.
